content: what you thought I'd leave these cheap trees as is yeah right hey guys welcome
back to Blackmagic craft so I've already reviewed these cheap holiday Christmas
village trees link up there if you missed it and they are perfectly
serviceable trees for tabletop gaming they look okay they're super cheap and
yeah not bad overall but you can make them look a lot better while still
keeping them super cost-effective I turned a bunch of these into a bunch of
these and they look way better more realistic just hell of a lot better the
good part is though it didn't really cost much in extra materials it was
pretty darn easy to do and they are super durable they're they're hard
they're not gonna shed a bunch of flocking everywhere they turned out
really good so let's take a look at how I did it I started by buying more trees
I figured if I was gonna do this I should just make a bunch of them I did
two packs worth of trees in total my initial thought was to make a bunch of
regular summer pines and some that I would rihwan her eyes so to speak with
better snow in the end I decided that two packs worth was actually what I
wanted to keep without snow so maybe in the future I'll get a third pack and do
more winter trees I had to somehow get off all of that snow flocking and the
easiest way to do this was just to fill up a sink full of water and throw the
trees in and let them soak for a bit it's a good idea to put down an old
towel for drying them a towel that you don't care about because when these
trees are wet they're gonna bleed a bit of green dye and it's definitely gonna
wreck or stain whatever towel they are left to dry on once the trees have sat
in the water for several minutes it's really easy to scrub off the snow
I used a brass wire brush for this the same one that I used for doing wood
texture on foam basically any stiff bristled brush or scrubber will work the
snow flocking comes right off after removing all the flocking I
separated the trees from the plastic bases at this point I still hadn't
decided if I would be reusing the bases or not but I wanted to make sure that if
I did they didn't get covered in flocking later so just in case I pray
today side and at this point I gave the trees a little bit of a haircut to get
rid of any wild stray fibers then it was time to flock the trees and in the past
I've used 3m super 77 spray adhesive to do this it works really well and it
instantly bonds has no drying time but because it's such a strong chemical
adhesive you really have to spray it outside and it has a very short working
time so that means I have to spray each tree outside individually and run back
into flock it I didn't want to do that I was doing a lot of trees so instead I
opted for the PVA method I prepared a dipping tub by cutting the
top off of a two-liter pop bottle in it I made a mixture of PVA glue and water
in an approximately 50/50 ratio in retrospect I should have made the
mixture before cutting off the top so I could just shake it up and then cut it
off yeah you live and learn with the mixture ready it was just a matter of
dipping the trees into the water down glue and letting the excess runoff then
sprinkling them with a heavy amount of fine green flocking I used woodland
Scenic's for this but really any brand would work the important thing is to use
finely ground flocking I tried a bit with coarser turf and honestly I didn't
really like the result it's also helpful if your trees are still slightly damp
from the washing as this will help the glue flow into every little nook and
cranny this can be pretty messy and you want something to catch all that stray
flocking so that you can recollect the excess later I found that a paint tray
liner worked perfectly for this
for drying I used a large piece of XPS foam to hold the trees I just poked in
some holes with a toothpick and then I was able to stand them up on their
little wire tree trunks if these were left like this the flocking would remain
pretty soft and would likely shed quite a bit over time in order to really lock
it in I wanted to completely soak the flock in more watered-down PVA glue I
was worried that if I dip them again all the flocking would just wash off so I
opted for spraying them again this would be messy so I covered my workbench in
garbage bags to protect it from overspray in order for the glue to
really soak in you want to first spray the flocking with something that will
help break the surface tension the simplest way to do this is by first
spraying them with water that has a tiny amount of dish soap or dishwasher rinse
aid mixed in I just used a little cheap dollar store spray bottle to do this
then with the flocking pre wetted I sprayed it again with a mixture of PVA
glue and water this time though the mixture was really watered down so that
it would spray probably around 80 percent water to 20 percent glue this is
a bit tricky as it tends to quickly clog up the spray bottle but it's worth the
hassle it's the next day I left these to dry
overnight because there was a considerable amount of very watered-down
PVA glue on them I was expecting the PVA to dry fairly hard and my hope was that
when I sprayed them the second time that it would harden them up even more but I
fully expected them to still be fairly soft and vulnerable and need another
coat of something I was very pleasantly surprised this morning to come
downstairs and feel these and they are rock friggin hard I feel like you could
cut somebody with these I'm blown away with how well this PVA spray worked it
is absolutely incredible I don't think these are gonna shed very much I'm still
gonna hit them with a clear coat just for good measure but damn this worked
really well way better than I thought it would
to make these even more bulletproof I also sprayed them with a coat of matte
varnish I don't think this was really necessary but hey it doesn't hurt to add
even more durability to your terrain
